title: Palladio (Jenkins)
text:
Palladio is a composition for <a href="string%20orchestra">string orchestra</a> by <a href="Karl%20Jenkins">Karl Jenkins</a>, written in 1995, with the title referring to the Italian <a href="Renaissance">Renaissance</a> architect <a href="Andrea%20Palladio">Andrea Palladio</a> (1508–1580). The work in three movements is in the form of a <a href="concerto%20grosso">concerto grosso</a>.
History.
<a href="Motif%20%28music%29">Motif</a>s of the first movement, Allegretto, were used for a TV commercial of <a href="De%20Beers">De Beers</a>, "A Diamond Is Forever", from 1993. Then Jenkins completed a <a href="Suite%20%28music%29">suite</a> of three movements in the form of a <a href="concerto%20grosso">concerto grosso</a> for string orchestra, named "Palladio", in reverence of the Renaissance architect.
"Palladio" was published in 1996 by <a href="Boosey%20%26amp%3B%20Hawkes">Boosey & Hawkes</a>. It takes about 16 minutes to perform. The composer comments: 
"Harmonious proportions and mathematics" play a role in <a href="Music%20and%20mathematics">music</a> as in <a href="Mathematics%20and%20architecture">architecture</a>. The architect Palladio based his designs on antique Roman models and studied especially the measurements of <a href="Vitruvius">Vitruvius</a>. Jenkins in turn based his music on Palladio's "harmonious mathematical principles".
The music, especially the first movement, has been arranged for different ensembles, including <a href="wind%20quintet">wind quintet</a> and <a href="wind%20band">wind band</a>. Jenkins made a version for piano and used the motifs of movement I for an <a href="aria">aria</a> "Exultate jubilate", related to his 70th birthday.
Scoring and structure.
The piece in three movements is scored for string orchestra.
Recording.
"Palladio" is featured on a 1996 CD "<a href="Diamond%20Music">Diamond Music</a>", played by members of the <a href="London%20Philharmonic%20Orchestra">London Philharmonic Orchestra</a>, conducted by the composer. It is combined with other music by Jenkins including variations from "<a href="Adiemus%20%28albums%29">Adiemus</a>" and his second string quartet. Movement I appears in other collections, such as "Karl Jenkins & Adiemus: The Essential Collection".
Escala version.
The English string quartet <a href="Escala%20%28group%29">Escala</a> recorded a version of Palladio in 2009 which featured on their <a href="Escala%20%28album%29">self-titled</a> debut album, following their appearance on the <a href="Britain%27s%20Got%20Talent%20%28series%202%29">second series</a> of "<a href="Britain%27s%20Got%20Talent">Britain's Got Talent</a>". It was released as a single and peaked at number 39 on the <a href="UK%20Singles%20Chart">UK Singles Chart</a> in the week ending 6 June 2009. The single spent one week in the top 40.
